Now you can fix your old 2D printer with your 3D printer! These are replacement paper tray tabs for HP PSC 12XX and 13XX printers.

Dremel method:
  • Print appropriate tab.
  • Cut tab to size with your Dremel.
  • Glue in place. Duco Cement recommended.
    • CAD method:
  • Take a picture of the break on your tray. Make sure the camera is normal to the broken side edge to get an accurate profile of the break.
  • Import the picture into your CAD program, scale it, and impose it over the model to cut the tab to fit your break.
  • Print your updated model.
  • Glue in place. Duco Cement recommended.

These are the plastic parts for the Estes MX Missile vintage rocket kit. Sized for Estes BT-60 tubing. The parts are Broken up into 10 easy-to-print parts that assemble with model cement or epoxy into parts nearly identical to the classic kit. You should refer to the link below for photos and assembly instructions for the original kit. You will need those to properly use these parts to recreate the kit. http://www.spacemodeling.org/jimz/est1916.htm The Fin unit requires support to print. If you are not satisfied with the supports your slicer gives you can enable custom supports from inside the SCAD file. The Lock Ring and Lock Collar are glued together and later glued into the body tube. just aft of the actual motor mount. The purpose of this ring is to lock the display nozzle and fin unit to the bottom of the rocket for flight. It does this using a bayonet style mount. The Motor Mount and Motor Tube are glued together and then glued into the Fin Unit using the assembled lock ring to properly space them. It is important to not glue the fin unit to the lock ring. Just use the lock ring to get the spacing right. The Nozzle, Tank, Plate and Nozzle Tube glue together to provide a display nozzle for when the rocket is sitting on the shelf. You do not glue it in the lock ring. It's designed to be removable and replaced with the fin unit for flight.

description.text: This is a design for rcexplorer's tricopter v2.5 http://rcexplorer.se/projects/2011/09/the-tricopter-v2-5/

The two STL files are for the top and bottom of the body of the tricopter. I used 10mm square armatures and bolted the frame together with M3 hex screws and lock nuts. Friction keeps the arms in place which means if you have a crash they have some movement and tend not to snap.
I've used velcro on the top plate to attach my control board, and receiver. My lipo is mounted underneath with a scorpion strap and slots nicely between the bolts. The hole on the bottom is purely to reduce weight (if you're using the scad file then comment out the indicated line to eliminate the hole and print the top).

title: Brenden Hurley
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Well another day goes by, and another summer helper is out the door. This college thing is starting to become a pain in our side. It's no fun losing them, especially when we have had it as good as we have. Brenden was our social media king and we will miss him dearly. His witty blog posts and clever picture selections are going to be greatly missed... It's going to be a challenge to live up to the high standards he's set. So to give thanks to our interns we have immortalized them on the internet, in PLA, and ABS.
If your company is in need of a 3D printing or social media specialists, feel free to download ours for your use! I have a hunch they won't be as helpful as the originals, but they're certainly nice to have around.

This print requires support for the chin. We sliced with ReplicatorG with external support and it worked great! All rafts and supports are easily broken off by hand. If you tend to be a perfectionist you can scrap off the stringies with a butter knife too.

A model of a defense wall for miniature wargaming. It is scaled for 28mm by default. the front section is 3 inches wide and the wings are 1.5 inches long each.

You can try printing this as one piece, but I have also provided three independent pieces that should print flat and glue together.
I printed one of these today and the wings are tapered just enough so that a stair stepping effect occurs on the front face of each wing. It isn't too bad, it sort of looks like seams in the metal, but wanted you to be aware. I will post pictures when I get a chance so you can see the printed model. If it isn't too hard to change the model, I will see if I can eliminate the stepping.

Update December 2017
We added a new cool textured flame and updated our thumbnail. The rocket was printed in Polyalchemy Silver Elixir PLA. Update:
We updated the model. It is now hollow and should have no errors in Simplify3D and it has flat bridges under the curved fins for easier printing on some machines. We also removed the center booster support so you must add support below the main nozzle or the print will fail. New video tutorial series on designing, slicing and printing the gCreate Rocket!
Part 1 & 2:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dz5APml1JqU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZIF53iyyjTU Part 3:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UsArmn30JdI To celebrate the launch of our new site we are uploading our official rocket complete with a smoke stand. This rocket comes in 4 parts and each one slips together.
We have printed this in various filaments including Colorfabb PLA, colorfabb bronzefill, woodfill, ABS, glow in the dark and several others. The bronzefill is by far our favorite.
Check out our site for more free models http://www.gcreate.com
The model was created in 3ds Max 2011 but due to the export/unit issues the model is scaled up by 2540%. You may have to scale down by .0393701 depending by your slicer software. In slic3r 1.1.6 it works fine. An interesting note, the smoke is actually a particle simulation in 3ds Max which i used meta particles and then heavily modified as a mesh. New Download!
Check out the remixed spiral vase rocket here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1535483 Another New Download!
Check out the Money Bank Rocket here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1555828

Update:
We recommend setting the "Solid infill threshold area" to be very small (1mm^2). This is the setting in slic3r but check your program. This will help the bottom nozzles to stop from breaking off. You can also screw them back on (which we did with the bronzefill) and then they will never come off.
We recommend printing this with a raft depending on your print surface. The model can be tricky to print until the 3 fins finally connect to the body of the rocket. After that it prints great.
We also recommend playing with different materials. This printed amazingly well in ColorFabb woodfill and bronzefill as well as various PLA filaments. It also prints great at half size if you want a mini rocket.
While this print doesn't require support, the center nozzle has built in support which breaks off after the print (if you want to put it on the smoke stand).

comments.text: It's a pretty cool model (My favorite on here, as far as retro looking rocket ships go), but there's an issue with how the support was designed. The thin walls get cut off in certain software, especially when scaled down. So, the base might get partially printed, but the upper portion doesn't since the walls taper in to such a thin degree. Ideally, it'd need to be modified, or if you could provide a version without the support. You're smart to include a support for that, but it just doesn't work in certain situations because of the above mentioned detail. I went through a few prints before I realized what was happening, and it was the remix that I ended up printing, since that fixed the issue. I think for everyone's sanity, it'd be good to fold those adjustments into the main model that is provided.

title: 2 Color 3d Business Card
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: 3d Printed 2 Color Business Card. It\'s the same size as a playing card (2.5in x 3.5in) so it\'s more like a plaque. Mostly it\'s to show what the detail capabilities are for your machine.

Large letters and Logo are printed separately in a different color and snapped into the card surface. The small lettering is etched into the card surface and is a little like scrimshaw. They should be colored in by a sharpie or other such thing to be legible. this is version 0.01 and needs a little redesign since skienforge has trouble with 1mm square or smaller \'pixel\' cutouts. typically having trouble with the number 6 or 8, or 9 and the letter a. also this version\'s border is currently glued down, but once I\'ve switch back to printing black on the next iteration will have a snapped on border like the Makerbot Coin MK2. I\'ll post .stl and originals in a bit after the small redesign.
I\'ll also put up a separate post with small letters and numbers that will print and be freely available for commercial use.

title: makerbot window clip for 1/8 inch clear plastic

description.text:
Yes, it is another makerbot window clip. this one is made so the window does not overlap the opening and interfere with the various screws and the display which are close to the openings.
it was based on jags window clip but i created it from scratch.

Print however many of them you will need, i used 3 on the sides and 4 on the front.
i used 10% infill 1 shell ABS, (replicator 2 profile  in replicatorG) you will have to make it more solid if you use PLA (rep 2 owners)
Then you need 3 bits of lexan, plexiglass etc. 1/8 thick. (i can make other thickness on request, i cant make the file parametric, because i made it in 3ds max)
2 Pieces are 8 3/4" square,  and one piece is 8 3/4 x 15"
everything just clips together, you dont need any screws or dissasembly.
If you wanted to completely seal the windows, you could put some of that sticky foam door sealer tape around the perimiter, i havent needed to do that yet, ill see what happens in the summer with AC and ceiling fan.

This extruder carriage has been built for the qu-bd single and dual extruder, but can be used to hold any extruder.

After making this part:
  • Add delrin wheels. Top wheel holes are for eccentric spacers, bottom holes are for 5mm screws. They are sized for Makerslide.
  • Add limit switch ( two small vertical holes)
  • Add belt vise (4 holes in a rectangular pattern) and capture belt.
    • You will need to change the cutout and drill holes to fit your extruder profile if it is not the qu-bd. To guarantee that you don't melt the carriage use a piece of 1/8" plywood at the base of the extruder as an insulator from transmitted heat.
Use this spoon to pick out olives, cherries, or other small, submerged items.  Enjoy!

The version pictured was printed in PLA with a 50% fill and .2mm layer height.
PLA is not dishwasher safe (due to warping) but ABS is.

description.text: Some connecting hub for car engine

I wanted more room in my medicine cabinet and so made this to hold my Advair Diskus vertically, reducing the footprint considerably.
My original version was a little tight side-to-side, so it would grip the Advair.  This version gives a little more clearance so that it should just sit in it without getting stuck, but I haven't printed this version yet.

The metal cube-wall hooks for hanging whiteboards can be very cheap and in some cases not even strong enough to hold up the larger whiteboards. It is v2 because I had to reinforce and adjust the design after the first version slipped off the cube wall and sprang across the room.
So I made a sturdier hook which works pretty well for the whiteboards with a metal frame.

Print with 100% infill. I recommend ABS over PLA as it seems like the flexibilty of ABS lends itself better to being a spring. Also, I suspect that ABS will fail more gracefully if you put the hook past its limits.
If you have a smaller whiteboard or only want to hang a coat or something, you could scale it down (in the z direction) quite a bit.

description.text:
A simple S3 cradle with inter-changeable bottom parts, two for desktop use, another for attaching to a standard camera tripod.
I've used the camera attachment a few times when I've run 'Lapse It' - a cool time lapse for Android. 
I've included a photo of my S3 on my small camera tripod, but it fits great on full sized tripods too.
[UPDATE] I've design a new pyramid style base as the tripod seemed a little unstable at times. The new base has a lower centre of gravity and is much more stable.

I printed this at 0.2mm on an Up Plus! printer. The tolerances for the slide section to connect the parts is pretty close so you may need to file a little plastic off to get a nice fit.
I needed to add a support structure to print the new pyramid base, but that might just be my Up! printer, it looks like the Replicator 2 is much better at printing without adding support.

If your sphero is strobing a blue greeny color, you need to reset it by running a magnet accurately around the equator of the sphero.
It looks easy in the tutorial video:
(www.youtube.com/watch?v=ah5G9_pJuYo&feature=youtu.be)
  • but it really is very difficult to do correctly, especially if you have shaky hands! The Sphero Magnet Resetter makes it easier to hold, control and turn the magnet accurately on the equator. It's easier for the younger kids to control also in their little hands! But overall it's more manageable for all ages.
    With my resetter, you simply put the magnet inside, put the resetter on the sphero and give it a turn.Then leave it on the charger for 2 hours and the sphero should be ready to go! It's that easy.
    My sphero often needs resetting and it still takes many tries to get it right, but with the resetter, it's way easier!!
    I've added photos of my entry. I had a 3D model printed in a Printing Shop. I DO NOT own a 3D Printer - unfortunately!

author: yhoppers

description.text: A.K.A. a Pythagorean cup.

This was printed as a test object to demonstrate how bell siphons work for aquaponics systems.  It will need to be water and air tight, so print it with 4 shells at .5 single wall thickness.  If your printer has a different wall thickness, download the .scad and adjust accordingly.
Print one tray and one bell, then you might want to do some finishing on the parts to make sure they're watertight.  Then the bell sits in the hex shaped cutout in the tray, with the holes down by the floor of the tray.
Begin to fill it with water... it will fill normally, until the water level gets to the top of the inner pipe, at which point all of the water will run out through the hole in the bottom of the tray.
This effect is useful for aquaponic and hydroponic systems, where a passive mechanism is needed to repeatedly flood and drain grow tables.

Hi, I'm riding a tap so you can click on fruit or in barrels.
Test was so patience.
greetings

description.text: This is a fan holder to cool down the processor board of MakerFarm Prusa i3 8".

IN THE PICTURES ABOVE, THE WHITE MOUNT IS V1, THE BLACK MOUNT IS V2.
This is made for a GoPro however, it is tight and trust me; I know. I made it tight so that you can file/sand it down yourselves. I had to sand mine according to mounts provided with my GoPro, After some filing/sanding, it should fit perfectly.

Print in PLA, not ABS. ABS will shrink and warp and the dimensions will not be accurate.
For a tight fit that will require sanding/filing, please download the original.
For a perfect fit that will not require sanding/filing, please download V2.

We did not like the little plastic bags with all the nozzles inside. So we decided to design a holder, following the "5S" methodology as best as possible. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5S_%28methodology%29 Because the thread on our nozzles is a standard M6 thread we decided to insert M6 Nuts inside of our PET printed Part.
By doing so, we think, that we can screw in the hot nozzle fresh of the printer without damaging your holder.

We wanted the holder to look like a thermometer from afar.
To achieve that we made the scale stick out to the left side.
Unfortunately PET is quite a bitch when it comes to retraction and string pulling, even the application of a hot air gun did not resolve the crappy look of our scale. So we just printed the scale in PLA and glued it to the side of our holder.

author: rapidaccess

description.text:
Here is a simple design for a bearing mount that can be used to hold an 8mm lead screw or 8mm guide rod.  I have been kicking around the design for a DIY CNC mill table using the Gen 3 MakerBot/RepRap motherboard and stepper driver cards.
The object accepts the 608 skateboard ball bearing and there are 2 mounting holes for 3mm or 4mm bolts to fasten the thing down.

I am beginning to enjoy using an HBP to run ABS raftless, and printing this object without one worked fine.  INFILL DENSITY in the SkeinForge FILL menu was set to 0.3 for my copies but may be set higher depending upon the user's end application.  
There is not a lot of work to do on these after printing - Scrape out the bearing opening of excess plastic then press fit the ball bearing in.  The fit is tight, but you can carefully add a drop of superglue between the mount and outer rim of the bearing if desired.  
The 2 block mounting holes might need a small amount to material removed from the holes, but I just pushed 3mm bolts through to take care of that when fastening the mount down.  Sanding with 220A gives the object a better look, but it will work fine without sanding.  
Use flat washers or cap headed bolts for mounting to increase the surface area holding the block.  A small headed bolt would put all kinds of stress on the mounting holes when tightened.

author: THECREATORPA

description.text: This can be assembled with no glue. It is a much more accurate replica that the one previously posted. It was designed from scratch, only using reference images of screen used blasters. It's fun to play with, take apart, and assemble. Most importantly, it was designed for 3d printing, so it's got curves in all the right places. This blaster was made at MarsCon this weekend. They told guests we weren't allowed to bring realistic-looking weapons into the convention, so I didn't. I just brought my 3d printer in and made the blaster there... Read more! http://toddblatt.blogspot.com/2013/01/scout-trooper-blaster.html updated handle: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44249 Created by Todd Blatt of Custom3dStuff.com

Things just snap together. Two pins to hold the handle to the main block. Slip the three cylinders onto the back plug, which goes into the back hole of the main block. the nozzle goes in the front of the main block. The guard goes into the handle. The small crosshair piece goes inside the back scope. Back scope goes into the front scope, and the entire scope assembly attaches to the rest of the blaster using the clip. You can also force a second crosshair piece into the tip of the scope front piece if you press it in from the inside, using a pen or something similar. The two big pieces and the clip were printed with 5% infill, and two extra shells. Basically everything else was 0% infill and 2 extra shells. You can print a spare nozzle in 'safety orange' to swap out when the local fuzz gives you a hard time. I like printing with the pads, and peeling them off when it's done. It'll keep things flatter when printing in ABS, even with the heated bed. The pads are also useful for part which have little surface area touchign the platform. I prefer these to using a raft because of how much more it'll hold down the part to prevent it from curling. I guess I'm a daredevil. The files in the .zip with 'z' in front of the file name don't have the pad. updated handle: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44249 -Todd

This is a small two-wheeled robot designed for pattywac's bearing contest. It is similar to other robots available on thingiverse, but it is unique in that it does not use gearmotors or continuous rotation servos, but plain dc motors and a makerbot-printed geartrain. Although the printed geartrain is incredibly noisy and not terribly efficient, it is much cheaper than any gearbox that one could buy. Also, it's printed on the makerbot, which is pretty neat. Features:
-Makerbot Printable Geartrain (8:1 reduction)
-Printable without heated build platform
-3mm holes in chassis and cover for easy modification/expansion
-Can accommodate motors up to 25mm in diameter (comes set for 22mm in diameter) and up to 30mm long.

This is the abbreviated version; see the README file for more detailed instructions. The robot is made of two identical halves, that each contain a wheel and the geartrain for that wheel. The wheel is clamped on the bearing with a M3 bolt that goes through the wheel and the output gear; the wheel and output gear shafts mesh inside the bearing bore to transmit torque. There are two middle gears between the output gear and the motor pinion. After the chassis has been assembled, a cover is attached. There are several options available. Cover_Grid.stl is a cover with 1cm spaced 3mm holes. The two arduino covers allow an arduino to be mounted on the top of the robot. Cover_Solid.stl is a cover with just screw holes and a hole for the motor wires. Cover_Blank.stl is a cover without the top and bottom faces filled in, to make making your own covers easier. The assembly instructions can be found at: http://www.flickr.com/photos/nickames/sets/72157624952160443/

description.text:
This is a remix of the DaniSaez Remix (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:419278) of my BCN3D+ Bowden extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:406531). Thanks to the great job of Dani, he greatly reduced the carriage width, but he needed to relocate the fan in the front of it. As I like to see my parts printing (call me maniac...), I decided to redesign some parts to put the fan in the back as originally, and this is the result.
Dani found An other issue. How to attach the small 25mm cooler fan to the carriage. He decided to glue it to the carriage (simply and effective), but I wanted to do it mechanically (Call me maniac again...;)). I've used the original RepRapBCN support adapted to my BCNozzle (It seems that I've the first version...).
Other improvement (in fact is the main improvement. Thanks to it the fan can be placed in the back...) is that the original layer fan support, now is has an other functionality, is the belt clamp too.
All the materials in the original things (see previous links) are valid excepting the parts attached to this one. All were printed in ABS but only the fan ring and the carriage plate, needs to be printed in this material.
Important, as I explained in the original thing, the best results were achieved with Cura. There you can find the config files especially for the BCN3D machine.

What I am trying to do is replace the entire "gantry" setup on my QU-BD 1up with something simple to print and simple to assemble. I have just gotten done re-designing my assembly. I think it looks promising but I haven't had a chance to print it and test it out yet.
More updates to come
.
Update #1
-Started printing some parts last night realized that for some reason my scale is off by 10. I don't know why. But printing at 10x scale seems to be working fine.
.
Update #2
-I printed and assembled the machine over the weekend. I did have to sand and file a few parts to make them work and the Y End needs to be mirrored so I had to install it backwards to fit the machine together. It is successfully making prints but there are a few more Revisions that I will add to make sure it is easier to assemble.
.
Update#3 I added extra support to REV1 Z plate and also shrank it to print easier on a 1up
.
Update#4 Just a quick update. I have been working on improving the design of the SparkinBot over the last week. I am making changes that will allow for simple adjustments to make sure everything is lined up correctly. I have also started on designing the bottom half of the machine to eliminate ALL MDF from the machine. I'm sorry I haven't uploaded any of these changes yet. I want to print them and test them before I release them. I feel like what I have already uploaded to thingiverse works and is an imrovement on the original design and I am trying to make all the parts I am re-designing backwards compatible with what I have already released. So if you wanted to start building it the way it is now newer parts will be interchangeable.
.
.
http://youtu.be/M-39utEwE_M

You will need to print the following:
1ea Z End
1ea Y End
1ea Extruder back
1ea Z plate top
4ea Bearing Holders
1ea Z plate Bottom
2ea Belt clamps
a total of 11 parts
the Sparkinbot stl isn't needed It is just to show the entire assembly.

description.text:
I am making a HHO cell. Tinkering tinkering tinkering...
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

description.header: Made 2 small tubes to make a single cell.

The new picture is a picture of my current cell. I am printing hydrogen1a.stl as a base and top. I will need to drill holes later so that I can keep the rods from touching the tubes. Then all I need to do is weld my ss wire to the tubes and rods.

Ok, as per thecrazy I am going to explain how I plan on making/using this. I just uploaded the base for the new cell "hydrogen1a.stl" which fits my tubes and stainless steel rods very nicely. They are both ss 316 and are resistant to hydrolysis. To put it quite simply... if you hook a battery up to water(doesn't matter what size really so long as it is above a certain tiny voltage) it will separate the water into its 2 component parts. 2 parts hydrogen and one part water. You can actually see the tiny bubbles form on the contacts if you drop a 9 volt battery in water(not recommended). Anyways, a inventor named Stanley Meyers said that with the proper frequency of current (somewhere around 20 hertz) you could break apart water more efficiently then normal methods. Blah blah blah, lots of conspiracy theories later after he was poisoned at a restaurant and lots of people are still trying to reproduce his work. Oddly enough when some one does come forward with proof of concept or a working model something happens to them and they are gone with the wind. Please note, the main difference with SM theory was that he used pure water without electrolytes and the cell did not over heat. People these days tend to sell or make cells that use some form of salt or potassium.... one which creates a bad after effect like hydrochloric acid. Anyways, if you are interested in making a cell I would recommend doing some research and you might be interested in watching this video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cqjn3mup1So

comments.text: Stan Meyers would be proud ..!!

comments.author: chris-nobody

comments.text: Meyer's work is based on the premis of electrical resonance. That is, taking a tesla-like resonant circuit, and essentially replacing the capacitor with Stan's water capacitor. Input the correct frequency into the circuit and you have tens to hundreds of kilovolts that can break the (covalent) electrical bond of water, without high amp flow/draw. This is due to the circuit design and reactance of such a design. There are MANY misconceptions of his work, so do be aware of that. I have studied his work for some time. Check out my VIC designs. Good luck!

description.text: Rhino3D has a powerful programming language; Grasshopper. This is a Grasshopper programme to generate moulds from any design. There is a video to show how it works. UPDATE 8.9.15: Grasshopper programme updated to reflect updates to Grasshopper versions since first published. Please remember to install Hoopsnake for Grasshopper too!

This is ONLY going to be useful to you if you have access to Rhino3D version 5 or later. There is a downloadable Grasshopper programme file and a demo file with a design and a spare. (Where you pour in your mould material). The output of the programme generates a MASTER mould. There are lots of customisation options - many of which you can see in the video. There are also plainly labelled tweaks within the programme for all manner of things; shell widths and slopes, bi-material offsets and interface configuration and much, much more. A typical use is to create a plaster master mould. Clay slip is then poured into the resulting plaster mould to generate a slip cast version of your design. The design of course has to be castable... Video available at http://youtu.be/3kU9nRV_ObA FEEDBACK APPRECIATED. Do always download the latest dated Grasshopper file!

description.text:
This is a 1/4" (6.35mm) spacer for PowerSpec 3D X Dual Extruder Printer, FlashForge Creator Pro, and Creator X with the newer platform so they can use a glass pane on the heated build plate.
After I got my 3DX, I realized it did not have the same support platform as the original Creator X that this unit is based on, so I could not use Creator X Z-axis spacers. I noticed some convenient screw locations, so I created this spacer to take advantage of the built-in screw location.
There is a 2 degree taper on the vertical slot to help the bottom of the spacer stay tight to the printer's base. You do not really even need to screw it down, but the option is available on the part if you want to.
Later I found out that the 3DX Printer uses the same base as the Creator Pro. Therefore, it should fit that model as well, but I do not have a Creator Pro to try it with.
Let me know your results and if you find other printers that this Z-axis spacer fits.

remixed_from.author: lucascorato
remixed_from.title: LUCAS extruder - finally a really universal extruder

description.text:
EDIT 23/09/2014
--
I have just uploaded a new 2.01 version with minor updates and I'm unchecking the "work-in-progress" checkbox, since I have been receiving lots of positive feedback about this project, from which I understood that it is working as expected. YAY!
From my personal experience, I can say that replacing and removing hotends for maintenance is a piece of cake, and I have been swearing a lot less lately.
I still need, though, to write a step-by-step guide and a complete hardware list as well. But time is short, and I apologize if I can't dedicate enough time to this thing or answer your private messages as quickly as I'd like to.
..........
This is the new version of my "universal" extruder (version 1 is here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:378330)
After the initial success of that project I decided to upgrade it and tried to address some problems:
• the extruder is attached directly to X carriage, so a table is no longer needed; it is far easier now to remove and re-attach the extruder;
• with less parts, it takes less time to print and saves printing material;
• without the table sides, the bottom part is free for every add-on you need: fans, fan ducts, servos etc
• extruder stepper is over the extruder body, improving balance and keeping gears towards the user;
• better wire management: there is lots of room to run wires for your servo and extruder and fans between the extruder and the x-carriage
• gears included: for this project you have to use kinda small bolt gear, otherwise it will get on the way of the hotend adaptor.
The fan duct holder must be developed, it's not as sturdy as I wanted.
For now, I abandoned the idea of using the hotend as a probe for the auto bed leveling system.
This project doesn't replace the previous, it's just an upgrade (although in a near future I might leave the other one, since this is very improved)
Special thanks to everyone who contributed with valuable ideas for this development, specially Thiago Peixoto http://www.thingiverse.com/thiagopeixoto16/about and the whole reprapbr group.
Teaser - http://youtu.be/Slvnd0vNulA (sorry, no subtiltes yet)

Print it as you print your extruders already, no special instructions!
I guess the design is pretty self-explanatory, but I'll try to make a step-by-step guide as soon as I can.
Any doubts please contact me!

comments.author: lucascorato

comments.text:
Actually most of the hardware is pretty straightforward, you'll probably need
• 3mm screws long enough to hold the pieces in place
• your favorite 8mm hobbed bolt
• a couple of two extra long screws, max 4mm diameter, for the idler
• one 5mm screw to hold the idler bearing in place (that will depend on the bore of your idler bearing, mine is 8mm so I use that ring that comes with the idler .stl
• three 688z ball bearings, but that will depend on your hobbed bolt and how you will keep the idler one in place, what is important is to respect the outer diameter of 16mm
• three linear bearings (don't remember model specification, but with an 8mm bore and 15mm OD)

title: Desktop Valentine Working Gears
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My husband, being a guy, would not even consider wearing my Valentine Gears Pin http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:410984, so I redesigned the pin to desktop size, altering its mechanism so that the upper right gear now has a little knob for turning and the frame goes all around the heart. It's as big as I can make on my printer's plate, so about 4" (100 mm) square. The photo is my "draft" copy - which worked as soon as I snapped on the gears. I'm so excited! Yeah! I made a movie on my iPhone, but I don't have the right file type to upload it - yet. I hope to make a much better looking one for my husband ASAP and will post a photo of it. I hope somebody does this with a better use of color than mine - please share a photo when you do!
YouTube video: http://youtu.be/0YQyrHCpOKY
UPDATE: I haven't had any trouble myself with the handle on the gear at the upper right of the heart, but I noticed in a recent print that it can come out really skinny. I liked the somewhat delicate shape, but thought it might be wiser to go with sturdy. So, I'm adding a plate for the gears that incorporates this sturdier handle.
I printed using 0.3 mm layers and 3 shells with 20% infill.

title: SSD Cage for 2 SSD's or 2.5 drives.

description.text:
I made a SSD Cage for 2 SSD's with screwholes already built in.
I used a caliper to measure all the dimensions, and the distance between the screwholes etc..
Mount the SSD's or 2.5" HDD's the opposite of each other.
Size: 95mm long x 84mm wide x 32mm high. The V2 version has more ventilation for air flow, uses less filament and is smaller and lighter than the original version.
V3 is just a bit more "fancy" and has more airflow, uses less filament and is smaller and lighter the the V2 version.
The updates is updated with some of kb0nly ideas, so a big Thank you to him! :)

Printing with 50% Rectilinear infill and 0.298925 layer height.
Using brown PLA @ 205C @ bottom layer and 190 on the remaining layers.
Mount the SSD's or 2.5" HDD's the opposite of each other.
Size: 95mm long x 84mm wide x 32mm high.

title: CTC replicator dual extruder for flexible filaments

description.text:
For those of you that like me didn't like what was out there to handle flexible filaments, this extruder designed for the CTC replicator dual it's a solid sturdier block that support the filament all the way to the hot end. (will allow you to adjust easily the high of your throat pipe)
Printed with 40% infill, 4 top and bottom layers and 3 perimeters at 40 mm/s.
Note: for those of you that will wonder how did I print outside the built plate...... Simplify3d (not cheap, but worth it)
Sorry, I forgot to add the knob. just upload the new file with it. UPDATE 08/20/14: after several hours of printing with ABS, one of the arms broke. I would recommend printing the arms with 100% infill instead of 40% as I indicated before. UPDATE 02/18/15: After several months of using the design, I did some modifications. The new extruder works much better and cooling to the aluminum block was improved. (Print both main bodies at 70% infill, the bearing holders at 100% and fan cover at 20%) Note: You will have to modify the start G-code to prevent hitting the extruder against the frame of the printer. Something like this: ; Replicator 1 dual start.gcode
M73 P0 ; enable build progress
G162 X Y F3000 ; home XY maximum
G161 Z F1200 ; home Z minimum
G92 Z-5 ; set Z to -5
G1 Z0 ; move Z to 0
G161 Z F100 ; home Z slowly
M132 X Y Z A B ; recall home offsets
M135 T0 ; load right extruder offsets
G1 X120 Y0 Z30 F9000 ; move to wait position off table
G130 X20 Y20 Z20 A20 B20 ; lower stepper Vrefs while heating
M126 S[fan_speed_pwm]
M140 S[bed0_temperature] T0
M134 T0 ; stabilize bed temperature
M104 S[extruder1_temperature] T1
M133 T1 ; stabilize extruder temperature
G130 X127 Y127 Z40 A127 B127 ; default stepper Vrefs
G92 A0 B0 ; zero extruders
M135 T1 ; load left extruder offsets
G1 Z0.4 ; position nozzle
G1 E25 F300 ; purge nozzle
G1 X120 Y0 Z0.15 F1200 ; slow wipe
G1 X120 Y0 Z0.5 F1200 ; lift
G92 A0 B0 ; zero extruders
M73 P1 ;@body (notify GPX body has started)
; end of start.gcode

you would need two 623zz bearings, 8 35mm M3 screws, 4 30mm M3 screws, 2 12mm M3 screws, 6 M3 nuts, 16 M3 washers,1 60mm M4 screw, 1 M4 nut and 3 M4 washers.
the 12mm screws hold the bearings with one washer on each side, the 35mm screws and 8 M3 washers assembles the fan, the block and nema 17 together, the 30mm screw with washers and nuts mount the extruder to the aluminum block, the M4 screw with the washers, nut and spring assembles the dual extruder tensioner.
If you find the guide hole to thin, use a small drill bit and drill it slowly to wide it out some more.
Good luck to all and hope it is useful to you.
just as a note: it works with binder clips

author: mganders

description.text:
A mountable box for the techzone USB-TTL board.
The rest of the techzone boards come with mounting holes, but the USB-TTL board doesn't. It is also the most likely board to be yanked when someone accidentally trips on or tugs the USB cable. This box allows you to mount the board to your machine with a bit more mechanical soundness.

Chainmail patch.
Can be printed without supports.
I've put flats on the bottom so that it sticks to the printbed better.

Update: Solidworks files added for mods etc. You will need the part file and assembly file too.
If you want more chainmail, edit the pattern in the assembly to make a bigger chainmail patch.

message = TOMMY
font_spacing = 19

I was asked to make some replacement Connect4 tokens for someone who had lost three of each colour. No problem I thought. Silly me - the real life tokens have 24 holes and 24 blips on them which enable one token to stack onto another. However, it was a good CAD exercise and although producing them requires a printer capable of some very fine detail, the ones shown here worked just like the originals.

There are two STL files here. One is a plain disk with a bevel on the top and bottom. The dimensions are 32mm diameter and 7.6mm height. However, to produce a good facsimile with the holes and blips, you will need to print two half counters using the other file and then glue them together.

comments.text: Very nice work! One more game saved ;o)

comments.text: Hello! I am happy to know that you liked the model. Actually the yellow one is a rendered image, sorry! The actual print is the red one (last image). But let me tell you that I have seen some really good finishing achieved with acetone vapor bath for abs prints. The interesting thing here is that you can use your heated bed on your 3d printer to do this. Here is an example https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jv-CbnB8Uz4 . Hope you find this useful !
comments.author: llPrototype

comments.text: Thanks a lot for sharing, very useful vid.  I am still getting used to my printer, I wouldn't say I am quite comfortable with slicing settings yet.
